Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium Support for the 2014 International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This student travel grant supports graduate/undergraduate and young researchers to attend the 2014 International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling and to participate in the Doctoral Consortium (ICAPS-DC). The ICAPS DC is a primary method for broadening participation and improving retention of doctoral researchers in the field of automated planning and scheduling. The DC at ICAPS 2014 is the 12th occurrence of the event, and takes place in June 2014 in Portsmouth, NH, USA. This is the first ICAPS held in the US since 2007. Those receiving awards through the Support Fund are able to participate in events, including but not limited to the DC, where they can receive career and research advice from peers and mentors, present preliminary results and plans for their dissertations, and build professional relationships. To support career development, invited speakers present emerging research opportunities, discuss research skills and the process of transitioning to the workplace after graduation. The participation of Ph.D. students at ICAPS 2014 and the DC is be beneficial to both the students and the international planning community, and to ensure cross-fertilization among researchers in areas of planning, scheduling, robotics, operations research, combinatorial search, knowledge representation and reasoning, and applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling (ICAPS) is the premier forum for researchers and practitioners in the field of planning and scheduling using artificial intelligence techniques. (See www.icaps- conference.org). The conference is the result of merging the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Planning and Scheduling (AIPS) and the European Conference on Planning (ECP). ICAPS-2014 will be the 24th conference in the series, counting the merged versions as well as the original two biennial conferences. Topics include all aspects of planning and scheduling theory and practice, including a wide spectrum of applications, such as in manufacturing, logistics, space systems, software engineering, robotics, education, and entertainment. The Division of Information and Intelligent Systems and its predecessors at NSF have funded and continue to fund many of the researchers in these fields, and much of the research presented at this conference. The ICAPS 2014 conference was held in Portsmouth, NH, USA in June 2014. It continued most of the activities of its predecessors, including the technical program, workshops, software demonstrations, and Doctoral Consortium.

The ICAPS Doctoral Consortium, in particular, provided an opportunity for Ph.D. students and junior researchers who were doing dissertation research on topics related to AI Planning and Scheduling to present their research, and to receive feedback from established researchers and from other students and conference attendees. It was intended to give students valuable exposure to outside perspectives on their work at a critical time in their research, and to provide a setting in which to explore their career objectives. The specific goals of the Doctoral Consortium were to:
    •    To provide a setting for mutual feedback on participants’ current research and guidance on future research directions; ?
    •    To promote contacts among PhD students working in the same area; ?
    •    To develop a supportive community of scholars and a spirit of collaborative research; ?
    •    To support a new generation of researchers with information and advice on academic, research, industrial, and non-traditional career paths; and ?
    •    To contribute to the conference goals through interaction with other researchers and participation in conference events.


Twenty-nine student and junior researchers participated in the 2014 DC, representing fourteen countries. NSF-supported travel grants ranging from $500-$1500 were provided to fifteen of the researchers, thereby partially supporting the attendance of more than half the DC participants.

Ten senior researchers each served as mentors to one or two DC participants, and spent the day interacting with the junior researchers in focused mentoring sessions. Each DC participant gave a spotlight talk on their work and engaged in technical discussions in the afternoon poster sessions. The schedule also included five talks delivered by senior researchers, discussion sessions on academic and industry career paths, and the history and future of the field.
